Maybe we need to require >0.43, like min_version 0.43.1 or kind of, then it will work in master I suppose"}, {'account_id': 14369, 'date': '2020-03-26 09:34:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Workflow-1

Hi Sagi,

Thanks for taking a look.  I'm aware of the test failure cause, this was the best that we could come up with for now.  I believe the next release (which includes the pieces I need) is expected in the next day or two.  My updates have been minor tweaks that I've bene making as I've been writing and testing the other modules.

I've been testing the modules locally with that check disabled.  I've a couple more cosmetic changes that I plan on pushing once SDK 0.44 is released, I'll add the Workflow -1 to make this obvious."}, {'account_id': 14369, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:15:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-03-26 18:29:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

[{'created': '2019-07-22 21:19:28.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] use openstacksdk for ironic module

This patches removes the ironic-client dependency from the
ironic module in favor of openstacksdk.

This is a test and very work in progress.

commit_message:
Use openstacksdk for ironic module

This patches removes the ironic-client dependency from the
ironic module in favor of openstacksdk.

Increase minimum required version of openstacksdk to use
recent added features.

Change-Id: I31964179835ad454e8205a59f483b419de4fb62d

a CentOS image:

commit_message:
Be moderate about disk space in the CI

We're close to the limit on some testing nodes, so, while building
a CentOS image:
1) Delete files as soon as we no longer need them.
2) Do not copy kernel/ramdisk unnecessary

Move the libvirt pool for testing VMs to /opt since some testing
nodes have small root partitions.

Also move irrelevant vars out of zuul definitions.

Change-Id: I2a34b19ee823109899dc21031e663a3ea848a5c5

subject: Fix pep8 issues in project
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 10969, 'name': 'Shnaidman Sagi (Sergey)', 'display_name': 'Shnaidman Sagi', 'email': 'sshnaidm@redhat.com', 'username': 'sergsh'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 13252, 'name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott', 'display_name': 'Dr. Jens Harbott (frickler)', 'email': 'frickler@offenerstapel.de', 'username': 'jrosenboom'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:12:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:17:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think that this is a valid change for a stable branch. We should rather fix the tests by capping pep8/flake8/whatever changed."}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:36:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:45:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jens Harbott, what exactly is not valid in the patch? This is necessary for fixing gates, otherwise nobody can merge anything. The only alternative is disabling pep8, flake8 jobs and checks. And I don't think it's a good alternative."}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-03-25 09:51:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

See https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/stable-branches.html#appropriate-fixes

IMO the correct fix for this is to cap hacking<2.0.0, which works just fine according to my local test.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-25 10:01:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Jens Harbott can you elaborate more please?'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-25 15:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-03-26 07:49:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Touching this amount of code for stylistic reasons is inappropriate in a stable branch. See https://review.opendev.org/714911 for an alternative solution.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-26 09:23:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

While in general I'd accept for smaller solution, but in this case it's really only stylistic change that shouldn't break anything. Also I don't see pep8 issues are going anywhere, there are quite a lot of them, including wrong indentation. Seems like pep8 jobs just didn't work before."}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-03-26 10:20:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The jobs were working, it is just that with hacking==2.0.0 a lot of conventions have been changed. For the stable branch, we should stick to the conventions with which it was developed, which is hacking==1.1.0. With the latter version, all pep8 checks are passing just fine, so the code is correct according to that definition of proper style, thus no need to change it.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-26 10:30:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

Jens is correct, these changes are not appropriate for backport.

Nearly every other project has hacking capped. For example:

https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/branch/stable/train/test-requirements.txt#L4

That is what should be done in stable branches to make sure they don't suddenly start failing with new linter releases."}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-26 12:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I see 5 spaces indentation in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/714899/2/openstack/tests/fakes.py line 258. AFAIK any conventions would fail pep8 for that.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2020-03-26 17:59:55.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

no interest to fix pep8'}]

commit_message:
Refactor memcached_servers

This patch aims to add a prefix for memcached_server
on each role to give the ability for deployers to
override the location of memcached cluster. I.e users
wants to create a single memcached cluster with k8s
for each service.

We also add pymemcache based on [1] and fix zun-docker
systemd config.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/711429

Change-Id: Ic7b31506177ebb0f4f24eaff4db134aace5c0b1a

commit_message:
Refactor memcached_servers

This patch aims to add a prefix for memcached_server
on each role to give the ability for deployers to
override the location of memcached cluster. I.e users
wants to create a single memcached cluster with k8s
for each service.

We also add pymemcache based on [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/711429

Change-Id: I2d0b500f002e457abcb1d5fe96bf554f96e5700e

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-39130 : FAILURE in 50m 49s'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-11-15 05:58:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/694428/1 : FAILURE in 2h 27m 52s'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-15 08:30:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I like this in principal. One thought was that we might leak things through exception messages which were never written for users. I'm perusing the output of:

  git grep -A "raise.*['\"]"

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py:        raise ValueError(_("Unrecognized read_deleted value '%s'")
nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py-                           % read_deleted)

nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py:        raise exception.AgentBuildExists(hypervisor=values['hypervisor'],
nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py-                        os=values['os'], architecture=values['architecture'])

nova/virt/disk/vfs/guestfs.py:            raise exception.NovaException(_("No operating system found in %s")
nova/virt/disk/vfs/guestfs.py-                                          % self.image)

nova/virt/disk/vfs/localfs.py:            raise exception.Invalid(_('File path %s not valid') % path)

nova/virt/libvirt/storage/lvm.py:            raise RuntimeError(_('Insufficient Space on Volume Group %(vg)s.'
nova/virt/libvirt/storage/lvm.py-                                 ' Only %(free_space)db available,'

nova/virt/libvirt/storage/rbd_utils.py:                    raise exception.Forbidden(_('no write permission on '
nova/virt/libvirt/storage/rbd_utils.py-                                                'storage pool %s') % dest_pool)

nova/virt/libvirt/storage/rbd_utils.py:            raise exception.NotFound('Pool %s could not be found.' % self.pool)
nova/virt/libvirt/storage/rbd_utils.py-


I didn't finish getting all the way through, and likely some/all of the above can't be raised to the API, but I think it's worth defining some policy around exception messages if we're going to do this. Some ideas, each with pros/cons:

* Don't display details unless the raised exception has an explicit 'user_message'
* Always display details, and fix leaks as we discover them
* Whitelist/Blacklist exception classes

Or perhaps this isn't an issue.'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-15 16:28:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I like this in principal. One thought was that we might leak things
 > through exception messages which were never written for users. I'm
 > perusing the output of:
 > ...

This is setting the instance action 'details' to be the exception 'message' and we routinely expose the exception 'message' to non-admin users by way of the instance.fault.message field in the GET /servers API. So conceptually, there is no additional exposure happening here.

The only potential issue I can think of is if we have a case where an exception 'message' with sensitive info in it is *not* written to instance.fault.message but *is* written to the instance action event details. This type of case would result in additional exposure than we have today.

But like I said before, conceptually this is doing no different than the way we already expose exception 'message' to non-admin users. So, separate from this patch, I think we do need a mechanism for flagging NovaException messages that contain sensitive info and not exposing them to non-admin users. https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/1851587 is a recent example of this.

Things like "raise exception.NotFound('Pool %s could not be found.' % self.pool)" are problematic because it's just a generic NotFound exception with sensitive info in it. That, for example, should be its own exception that has a non-admin friendly 'user_message' on it, or something like that.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 21:00:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yeah what melwitt said - the goal here is to expose the same thing available to the user via fault message when the server is in ERROR status. That said I need to resolve that FIXME in the code because of the weird serialize_args decorator in the object code but I didn't want to spend too much time on that until I had wider input from people saying they think this is worthwhile since I'll have to write a spec for the API change."}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-11-21 22:11:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-22 18:37:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-17 21:44:48.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This was a PoC which I'm not going to be working on anymore. It would require fixes for the serialized version of the fault message as noted inline but that shouldn't be too hard. The API change itself would require a spec for the new microversion but it's pretty straight-forward."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-03 09:00:54.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-14 23:30:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Store instance action event exc_val fault details

The InstanceActionEvent.pack_action_event_finish metho was
not storing the exc_val in a field that was actually part
of the data model so it was never stored ("message" isn't a
column in the instance_actions_events table, "details" is).

This formats and stores the exc_val, if provided, using the
same utility code that is used to record the message for
an instance fault record.

Eventually we can build on this in the os-instance-actions API
by exposing the fault details to the user without needing to
expose the traceback (like the server fault "details" traceback).

Part of blueprint action-event-fault-details

Change-Id: Ie3e11b38aac251c3f8911ed57dc5e7503aa91301

commit_message:
Store instance action event exc_val fault details

The InstanceActionEvent.pack_action_event_finish method was
not storing the exc_val in a field that was actually part
of the data model so it was never stored ("message" isn't a
column in the instance_actions_events table, "details" is).

This formats and stores the exc_val, if provided, using the
same utility code that is used to record the message for
an instance fault record.

Eventually we can build on this in the os-instance-actions API
by exposing the fault details to the user without needing to
expose the traceback (like the server fault "details" traceback).

Co-Authored-By: Brin Zhang <zhangbailin@inspur.com>

Part of blueprint action-event-fault-details

Change-Id: Ie3e11b38aac251c3f8911ed57dc5e7503aa91301

python-base has versions available now, defaulting to 3.7. Update
our config to 3.7 to be explicit about what we're using. This will

Change-Id: I40ffde91808a8bb95479697b9127dba16de8a8cd

commit_message:
Be explicit about python version in image

python-base has versions available now, defaulting to 3.7. Update
our config to 3.7 to be explicit about what we're using. This will
let us update the version as we feel like.

Change-Id: I40ffde91808a8bb95479697b9127dba16de8a8cd

commit_message:
Make the sleep duration in DaemonStrategy._run() configurable

Add a "healtcheck_interval" option to set the sleep time.
The default is 0.1s

Change-Id: If2e436a5cdbaa25179eb50caabe7d7788c4644c5

commit_message:
Hash the rescue_password

In order to provide increased security, it is necessary
to hash the rescue password in advance of it being stored
into the database and to provide some sort of control for
hash strength.

This change IS incompatible with prior IPA versions with
regard to use of the rescue feature, but I fully expect
we will backport the change to IPA on to stable branches
and perform a release as it is a security improvement.

Change-Id: I1e118467a536229de6f7c245c1c48f0af38dcef2
Story: 2006777
Task: 27301

[{'created': '2020-03-20 07:23:06.000000000', 'message': 'Use new line for list joining

Since we accept list of hosts for different parts, we should ensure we
get one item per line instead of joining everything as a single string.

Change-Id: I7e520035f24503e59840b34e5b2d9e9966cd6ca4
'}, {'created': '2020-03-20 15:58:01.000000000', 'message': 'Rework how we push the content in the file

Since we allow to pass lists, we can't just use |join('').

In addition, using the multi-line support in YAML via the "|" creates
some issues when we want to use |join('\n'): it gets escaped, meaning we
end with a one-line content with some \n entries.

The present patch ensures that:
- generated content is still pushed in a fact to not lose time
- static content (lists) is properly treated and outputs correctly

Change-Id: I7e520035f24503e59840b34e5b2d9e9966cd6ca4
'}, {'created': '2020-03-23 07:42:10.000000000', 'message': 'Rework how we push the content in the file

commit_message:
Rework how we push the content in the file

Since we allow to pass lists, we can't just use |join('').

In addition, using the multi-line support in YAML via the "|" creates
some issues when we want to use |join('\n'): it gets escaped, meaning we
end with a one-line content with some \n entries.

The present patch ensures that:
- generated content is still pushed in a fact to not lose time
- static content (lists) is properly treated and outputs correctly

Change-Id: I7e520035f24503e59840b34e5b2d9e9966cd6ca4

commit_message:
Update peers with API addresses

Create a default_update_peers which all API charms can use to publish
their admin, internal and public addresses to their peers.

Change-Id: Iacfdc2a0247f35d0bddfef47c9dd5d4cf66cd309
Closes-Bug: #1858132

commit_message:
Use governance_consistency.py for MembershipFreeze

The new governance_consistency.py tool lists all inconsistencies
between deliverables defined in openstack/releases and deliverables
defined in openstack/governance. Using it instead of the
membership_freeze_test tool (which only listed deliverables defined
in governance that did not have a corresponding deliverable file)
gives us the chance to fix all inconsistencies before milestone-2.

Change-Id: I34c2454082054b6e49edf16784e0e9213799ecc1

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-05 20:06:51.000000000', 'message': 'Adding system BIOS management command

Adding BIOS management command:

     sushycli system bios show
     sushycli system bios reset
     sushycli system bios set [attributes]

these commands allow to show current BIOS settings, reset it to defaut or
update one or many BIOS attributes that requires a system restart.

Change-Id: If02304177c914146b78e731b085fe988685e5b85
Story: 2006608
Task: 36776
'}, {'created': '2020-03-10 10:48:29.000000000', 'message': 'Add system BIOS management command

this change illustrate three BIOS management commands:

 sushycli system bios show #show BIOS attributes
 sushycli system bios reset #reset BIOS attributes to default
 sushycli system bios set BootMode=Bios [key=value] #update attributes

show and reset BIOS commands require "commun" attributes/arguments as:
              --username=jelly --password=fish
              --service-endpoint=http://fish.me
              --system-id=/redfish/v1/Systems/1

set BIOS command requires one more attribute(s), which is the bios
attribute(s).
set bios command allows to update one or many BIOS attributes at once.

Noting that The standard way to enable these applied changes to
BIOS settings is to restart the device.

Change-Id: If02304177c914146b78e731b085fe988685e5b85
Story: 2006608
Task: 36776

commit_message:
Add system BIOS management command

Adds three BIOS management commands:

 sushycli system bios show # show BIOS attributes
 sushycli system bios reset # reset BIOS attributes to default
 sushycli system bios set BootMode=Bios [key=value] # update attributes

Likely, system reboot will be required for the changes to take
effect.

Change-Id: If02304177c914146b78e731b085fe988685e5b85
Story: 2006608
Task: 36776

commit_message:
Fix build-images for centos8 jobs set tripleoclient and image-yaml

As seen in v9 of testing at [1] we need to set the right tripleoclient
package and pkg_mgr as well as point to the right image-yaml for the
image build command generated from the template. Tracked by tripleo-ci
squad in [2]

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/25796/9
[2] https://hackmd.io/7MBqFHurTA2e5H8kYRwgag#Reviews-still-in-play-to-addmove-jobs

Change-Id: I8d1205751ea123e0d80914b94558f7d4e718922c

Don't want to get into a religious war here, but based on the discussion associated with this in IRC I think that a compromise might be necessary.  Understand that the vendor removed this and when I approved it at the time I assumed that the vendor knows best.  With that said, it is not possible for vendors to know what every customer situation may be.  So, if we have a customer/user that is negatively impacted I think reverting this and adding some sort of config option to optionally enable the code is an appropriate compromise until the vendor comes up with a better solution."}, {'account_id': 26077, 'date': '2020-01-16 00:39:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Build failed.

        https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GerritJenkinsGit#Test_Failures.

For 3rd party ci contact info: 
        https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ThirdPartySystems/Infortrend_Storage_CI



- infortrend-cinder-volume-fc http://openstack.infortrend.com/1931/702730/1/check/infortrend-cinder-volume-fc/cc21dc2f83802b4f69707f77536548e326499935 : FAILURE

- infortrend-cinder-volume-iscsi http://openstack.infortrend.com/1948/702730/1/check/infortrend-cinder-volume-iscsi/cc21dc2f83802b4f69707f77536548e326499935 : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-16 13:19:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Don't want to get into a religious war here, but based on the
 > discussion associated with this in IRC I think that a compromise
 > might be necessary.  Understand that the vendor removed this and
 > when I approved it at the time I assumed that the vendor knows
 > best.  With that said, it is not possible for vendors to know what
 > every customer situation may be.  So, if we have a customer/user
 > that is negatively impacted I think reverting this and adding some
 > sort of config option to optionally enable the code is an
 > appropriate compromise until the vendor comes up with a better
 > solution.

No religious wars here, we just need to make sure we are doing the right thing.

Presumable VMware had a good reason fro removing the code. We need to make sure they are on board with this. They have visibility into a lot more deployments than any of us. I would expect they reverted the last change because of a real need to do so, not because they were just looking at ways to make using their product with Cinder worse.

As discussed on IRC, we really need something posted to the mailing list to get feedback on this. I've also just added Vipin to this review since he was the one that proposed the removal.

It may well be that the benefits of that code outweigh the impacts they were seeing, at least on some deployments, but we need the subject matter experts input here."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2020-01-16 13:51:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If you look at the original revert patch by vipin, the reason for his removal patch was due to running rally tests and hammering the system and it causing a 20% performance reduction.   It wasn't even a real world customer issue, nor was it due to a failure.   We use this driver (Queens) with the stats collection in place for proper scheduling and provisioning.   We should never have allowed the complete removal of stats collection against a driver unless it's utterly broken.  This obviously negatively affects customers that are using the driver."}, {'account_id': 24921, 'date': '2020-01-19 17:48:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

* Hedvig-CI http://os-logserver.hedviginc.com/refs/changes/30/702730/1 : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 9171, 'date': '2020-01-20 21:13:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

I did notice other problems in that patch, but performance issue was the main motivation for the revert. Also, fix for these other problems may further degrade the performance because that requires additional vSphere API calls. See the comments for more details. As Jay said, we can add a config option to enable/disable this code path, but we should make sure that this patch works as intended (minus the performance issues).

It took us a lot of effort to meet the scalability requirements of our customers/community (for e.g. see https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1556902). We had to optimize datastore related API calls to work against large customer deployments. I understand that we need to fix the stats for better scheduling decisions. Apart from the problems mentioned in the review comments, we should also consider the following (may be in a future patch):

* Since we aggregate the capacity of all datastores in the stats, scheduling decision can go wrong since there may not be a single datastore large enough to hold the requested volume size. 

* Specifying a value for the new option 'vmware_storage_profile' results in stats collection only for a selected set of datastores. So we should document that the volume type extra-specs should only contain profiles from this option. Even in this case the scheduling decision can go wrong (as mentioned above) due to reporting of aggregated capacity. We should also the consider the case where one or more profiles specified in vmware_storage_profile may not have any matching datastores.

A better solution would be to expose each datastore as a pool for stats reporting because aggregating the capacity like this may not help in better scheduling decisions.

I'm no longer maintaining the VMware Cinder driver. I hope the current maintainer will follow up."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2020-01-21 08:59:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the feedback Vipin.   There may be better ways of implemented the stats collection for this driver, but without anything the scheduling is entirely broken.

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-15 19:11:55.000000000', 'message': "Vmware: Revert the volume stats revert.

This patch reverts the removal of the collection of volume stats
from the vCenter.   Of course there is a performance hit when
collecting volume stats against a backend as compared to doing
nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864
"}, {'created': '2020-02-12 01:04:40.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Vmware: Revert the volume stats revert.

This patch reverts the removal of the collection of volume stats
from the vCenter.   Of course there is a performance hit when
collecting volume stats against a backend as compared to doing
nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This is a WIP currently to get agreement on re-enabling
the stats.   If we agree, I'll update the unit tests and remove
WIP.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864
"}, {'created': '2020-02-17 15:28:44.000000000', 'message': "Vmware: Revert the volume stats revert.

This patch reverts the removal of the collection of volume stats
from the vCenter.   Of course there is a performance hit when
collecting volume stats against a backend as compared to doing
nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This patch includes a new vmware driver config optiont that allows one
to enable the stats collection, so that a deployment with this driver
can actually work with the scheduler.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864

"}, {'created': '2020-03-18 19:34:40.000000000', 'message': "Vmware: Revert the volume stats revert.

This patch reverts the removal of the collection of volume stats
from the vCenter.   Of course there is a performance hit when
collecting volume stats against a backend as compared to doing
nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This patch includes a new vmware driver config optiont that allows one
to enable the stats collection, so that a deployment with this driver
can actually work with the scheduler.  When a driver doesn't report
any statistics, the scheduler has no way to determine the capacity
utilization of the driver and will always assume it can take a
provisioning request. This is especially problematic in a
heterogeniously deployed environment, where other drivers do report
valid stats.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864

nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This patch includes a new vmware driver config optiont that allows one
to enable the stats collection, so that a deployment with this driver
can actually work with the scheduler.  When a driver doesn't report
any statistics, the scheduler has no way to determine the capacity
utilization of the driver and will always assume it can take a
provisioning request. This is especially problematic in a
heterogeniously deployed environment, where other drivers do report
valid stats.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864

commit_message:
Vmware: Revert the volume stats revert.

This patch reverts the removal of the collection of volume stats
from the vCenter.   Of course there is a performance hit when
collecting volume stats against a backend as compared to doing
nothing.  The problem with not having any stats collection is that
the scheduler can't schedule properly against this driver, especially
when there are multiple of them deployed and heterogeniously against
other backends.   This revert fixes existing deployments against
this backend.

This patch includes a new vmware driver config optiont that allows one
to enable the stats collection, so that a deployment with this driver
can actually work with the scheduler.  When a driver doesn't report
any statistics, the scheduler has no way to determine the capacity
utilization of the driver and will always assume it can take a
provisioning request. This is especially problematic in a
heterogeniously deployed environment, where other drivers do report
valid stats.

This reverts commit f3ee3dbf4e4794d77cf263be3eec144328a3bedf.

Change-Id: Ifdd9b89e00de692a7a9e121ed421b921aa8bfc70
Closes-Bug: 1859864

commit_message:
Generate title lines based on length

With warnings treated as errors in the docs build, when the cycle name
size varies it results in an error with the RST title line length not
matching the text length.

Change-Id: Ic5da3fd11c98c1da869fe9cd9d7d285a36222236
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2019-06-17 22:59:37.000000000', 'message': 'create initial image metadata prefilter

- This change adds doc string params for current
  request filters
- This change adds a config option for the new
  image metadata prefilter
- This change chreates a table driven prfilter
  with no current transforms which will be extended
  in follow up patches.
- This adds basic unit test of the table driven prefilter

Partial-Implements: bp/image-metadata-prefiltering
Change-Id: I257ff81e23cdae6f2b62ec3d071b8f8f32d97781
'}, {'created': '2019-06-21 03:04:32.000000000', 'message': 'Add transform_image_metadata request filter

- This change adds 3 helper functions validate_traits,
  add_trait and transform_trait.
- This change refactors the require_image_type_support
  prefilter to use the helper functions.
- This change adds a table driven prefilter
  to transform image metadata into required traits.
- This change adds a new config option to enable
  the transform_image_metadata request filter.
- This change order the request filters alphabetically.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/652996
Partial-Implements: blueprint image-metadata-prefiltering

commit_message:
Add transform_image_metadata request filter

Add a table-driven prefilter to transform image metadata into required
traits. This requires a new config option to make the filter optional.

Change-Id: I257ff81e23cdae6f2b62ec3d071b8f8f32d97781
Implements: blueprint image-metadata-prefiltering
Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add link to image sharing api docs

The add|update_member methods of images take keyword arguments which
are documented in the api reference. Thus add a link to the docs so it
can be found easier.

Change-Id: I37eb80be164f179b4afc2dc36be3c5e10b3e7e52

subject: Remove duplicated cinder-backup.yaml
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-26 15:04:59.000000000', 'message': "Remove duplicated cinder-backup.yaml

Currently we have cinder-backup.yaml under environments directory and
environments/service directory, and these two files have the exact
same content.

Let's remove the one in services directory to have only a single
file, and also have all the cinder-related environment files in
the same level.

Change-Id: I9e256aa919c17148adccbd28aee11a6f84515c47
"}]
commit_message:
Remove duplicated cinder-backup.yaml

Currently we have cinder-backup.yaml under environments directory and
environments/service directory, and these two files have the exact
same content.

Let's remove the one in services directory to have only a single
file, and also have all the cinder-related environment files in
the same level.

Change-Id: I9e256aa919c17148adccbd28aee11a6f84515c47

commit_message:
Add `manager vmedia` commands

This command displays available virtual media devices and allows to
mount/unmount selected device.

The implemented commands are:

	sushycli manager vmedia show

	sushycli manager vmedia eject [--force] ...

    sushycli manager vmedia insert ...

Change-Id: I021aeafdb21d9aaa77a7f303988a6ab7a2e51127
Story: 2006608
Task: 36776

1.0.0 has been tagged and I don't think we can claim this as bug fix.

We do not use subcommand anywhere in glanceclient so I think this is good discussion to have if we want to move to that direction. We should do them all (images, tasks, metadefs, etc.) then at once. This would be good spec to file for M where we probably will have next major release bringing artifacts in as well."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-08-31 19:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified+1

IMHO this significantly improves the user experience.

I can't see why we wouldn't want this in 1.0.0.

I don't follow the argument that we would need sub-commands for everything if we did it for metadefs.

Ideally this would be backwards compatible (I've asked Niall to see if that is possible)."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2015-09-01 11:27:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Stuart, As said 1.0.0 has been released. This was not included in. Would it had been proposed early enough to discuss this through and have time to merge this before 1.0.0 release, yes I would have agreed on that.

If backwards compatibility can be achieved without getting even messier situation where we're now, yes, why not include it to 1.x.y and then just remove the old ones in 2.0.0 for example.

Still I'm not sure if this warrants as bug fix and why we should not subcommand the rest as well for consistency."}, {'account_id': 17116, 'date': '2015-09-01 13:57:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-09-01 15:58:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

This probably needs to be a bit more informative (ie the user needs to be able to discover the supported sub-commands):

$ glance help metadef
usage: glance metadef <operation>

Use this to manipulate the metadefs.

Positional arguments:
  <operation>  Insert one of the metadef operations.



Also, the help for the subcommands doesn't seem to be totally tied together?



$ glance help metadef namespace-list
usage: glance [--version] [-d] [-v] [--get-schema] [--timeout TIMEOUT]
              [--no-ssl-compression] [-f] [--os-image-url OS_IMAGE_URL]
              [--os-image-api-version OS_IMAGE_API_VERSION] [-k]

Erno, I'm not sure I follow your last commnent. I guess you're referring to the decision of using a common CLI for  OpenStack but I don't think that should impact this work.

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-31 13:55:43.000000000', 'message': "Move metadef into sub-commands

This changes the behaviour of the client so all the metadef commands
are now subcommands. For example to run what was previously was 'glance

commit_message:
Move metadef into sub-commands

This changes the behaviour of the client so all the metadef commands
are now subcommands. For example to run what was previously was 'glance
md-namespace-list' is now 'glance metadef namespace-list'.

This change allows for backwards compatability with the old style of md-*
commands so it will not break any scripts that reply upon that behaviour.

Change-Id: I42d07540c276e306105fa1d59585d63aa1c9c0b8
Closes-bug: 1489534

commit_message:
Fix messy request Id handling

Adds docstring parameter for return_req_id and stops relying on
**kwargs for receiving it. Makes the functionality lots more
understandable.

Change-Id: Ic7fe42bd1c606b7b4f6f562ac5d042ee50132984

(2 comments)

Is it a good idea to use plain encode instead of safe_encode from oslo encodeutils? It does just what you want with some additional checks.'}, {'account_id': 12071, 'date': '2015-10-09 03:34:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)

Hi Kiril, thanks for your feedback!

I believe that using safe_encode in the place of more explicit code (even if it does mean an additional line of code) is important because safe_encode implements several (effectively implicit) behaviours, some that might not be wanted. For example the transcoding behaviour which is quite dangerous when presented with non-ASCII (high-bit) input byte strings.'}, {'account_id': 12071, 'date': '2015-10-09 03:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Kirill: I also apologise for mis-typing your name in my response!'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-12-09 12:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

commit_message:
Fix encoding of filter arguments in request URL

Previously, unicode filer arguments were lazy-transformed.
It broke on actual unicode filter arguments. This patch
introduces explicit encoding of those arguments.

Change-Id: Ic8571b4c3dace79e3ad221310dd885be64789a3f
Partial-Bug: #1472999

was in a rush earlier so forgot to mention, we're in a soft string freeze where we could give exceptions to strings that are release critical until hard string freeze overlapping with rc1 http://releases.openstack.org/newton/schedule.html

since the changes here are not new and do not look like something that will affect the release, as they've been around for a while and looks like there's no bug associated with them.

we need to create a bug for these changes, document what's missing and include coverage information in the commit message to ensure that we cover ground for missing i18n changes and close that bug therein."}, {'account_id': 2537, 'date': '2016-09-16 22:34:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Use i18n for help text

There are some missing translations for help text in glance
utility scripts. We should use i18n to wrap help text with
_(), so the text will get translated. I have check the whole
glance project and make sure no other help text need to be
modified.

Change-Id: Id9431c4ab65bbe312e73b0ee9c6a6f979c8bd34a
closes-bug:1624784

subject: Use i18n for help text

commit_message:
Use i18n for help text

There are some missing translations for help text in glanceclient
utility scripts. We should use i18n to wrap help text with _(),
so the text will get translated. Some help text including command
need not to translate in order to avoid the translation errors.

similar patch:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/367795/

Change-Id: I1f46513d4e7dbe19fe9592af9785d7816397a050
closes-bug:1624784

If we don't give this validation we are getting the following error: 
400 Bad Request
Provided object does not match schema 'image': u'niteshhkfjskdfsghfjdkghfdkjghfjkdgnjkdhfdkgfdkgsdfklgsdfjkghjsdfkghfdjkghfdkjghfdjkghfdjkghfdjkgfjdksghjkdfghdfgjkhfdsjkghfsdjkghfdgjkhsdfgjkhsfgjknsfdgkjfdgkljfdgksljdfgksldfjgklfjdsgkljgsjdflkgjskldfgjsdlkfgjksdlfgjsdlkfgjsfkdlgjsldfkgjlkdfsjgkldfjglksdfjgklsdfjglkfsdjglksdfjjglksdj' is too long  Failed validating 'maxLength' in schema['properties']['tags']['items']:     {'maxLength': 255, 'type': 'string'}  On instance['tags'][0]:     u'niteshhkfjskdfsghfjdkghfdkjghfjkdgnjkdhfdkgfdkgsdfklgsdfjkghjsdfkghfdjkghfdkjghfdjkghfdjkghfdjkgfjdksghjkdfghdfgjkhfdsjkghfsdjkghfdgjkhsdfgjkhsfgjknsfdgkjfdgkljfdgksljdfgksldfjgklfjdsgkljgsjdflkgjskldfgjsdlkfgjksdlfgjsdlkfgjsfkdlgjsldfkgjlkdfsjgkldfjglksdfjgklsdfjglkfsdjglksdfjjglksdj'
    (HTTP 400)
It is very difficult to understand, so for better understanding i've added validation and giving a simple error as "Tag length should be less than 256 (HTTP 400)"'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2017-07-20 15:57:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I agree with Mike and Erno.  The problem you are addressing is that you want to make the error message more informative to end users.  Erno points out that schema-validation will catch this problem, and Mike points out that if the length is changed server-side, this code will be out of date (though the schema will still be correct).  Maybe the thing to do is make the call, but if it results in an exception, parse the exception to see if it's because of tag length, if so, translate to a meaningful message (getting the length limit from the exception), otherwise, just re-raise the exception.  Just an idea."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-26 14:30:30.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Erno is right, we should not hard code things in the client.'}]

subject: Allow infinite retrying on the expected db errors
messages:
[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 13:15:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-04 13:36:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Hello,

Do you think it's possible to implement some related tests in [1]?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/tests/test_api.py#L201"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-04 16:49:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-03-11 14:52:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Looks like I'm not the first person to ask for tests here. Add those and we'll be much happier, I assure you :)"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-11 14:55:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

infinite retries makes me a bit nervous, because that's how people perceive that an app is permanently "hung".   Just curious how do Nova etc. deal with this case, where the database can be stopped for any amount of time, and then upon starting it, they wake up?  does nova etc. have their own version of this decorator that retries infinitely or is there some other mechanism that is "retrying" ?'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-11 14:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-11 14:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

taht is, infinite "retry" on "database is not available" is useful, whereas infinite "Retry" on "database is deadlocking" is dangerous.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:04:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

that's correct but we only give users a tool, right?
shall I prohibit its potential misuse?"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:22:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think we should be clear on the use case.  

if the retry is infinite in a case where someone is waiting on their commandline to return a response, but the database is stopped, that's bad - their commandline will hang indefinitely rather than just saying, the database isn't running.

if the retry is in a daemon process that represents that daemon's normal permanent process of getting work to do, and it wants to keep retrying until the database is started, that's good.

but nova, neutron, keystone etc and other services already do this somehow.   what is the mechanism by which they are doing this?"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:42:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-11 15:48:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-12 08:09:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-24 07:58:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

hi, any updates for this?
unit tests had been added'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-24 11:15:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Should be rebased on latest commit to avoid mox issues since mox have been dropped previously else unit tests will fail with this parent commit.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-24 11:20:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Should be rebased on latest commit to avoid mox issues since mox
 > have been dropped previously else unit tests will fail with this
 > parent commit.

Should only be needed for local testing. In gate, and when merging, this will get rebased. So no need to rebase on its own otherwise.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-25 07:27:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-25 10:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review

> > Should be rebased on latest commit to avoid mox issues since mox
 > > have been dropped previously else unit tests will fail with this
 > > parent commit.
 > 
 > Should only be needed for local testing. In gate, and when merging,
 > this will get rebased. So no need to rebase on its own otherwise.

right'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-25 14:16:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@Bogdan: thanks for unit tests.

I agree with Mike we should be cautious with this kind of mechanism, to avoid.

 > I think we should be clear on the use case.
 > 
 > if the retry is infinite in a case where someone is waiting on
 > their commandline to return a response, but the database is
 > stopped, that's bad - their commandline will hang indefinitely
 > rather than just saying, the database isn't running.
 > 
 > if the retry is in a daemon process that represents that daemon's
 > normal permanent process of getting work to do, and it wants to
 > keep retrying until the database is started, that's good.
 > 
 > but nova, neutron, keystone etc and other services already do this
 > somehow.   what is the mechanism by which they are doing this?

@Bogdan: have you some info to bring to the Mike's question?"}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-25 14:17:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> @Bogdan: thanks for unit tests.
 > 
 > I agree with Mike we should be cautious with this kind of
 > mechanism, to avoid.

to avoid to hide some issues.

 > 
 > > I think we should be clear on the use case.
 > >
 > > if the retry is infinite in a case where someone is waiting on
 > > their commandline to return a response, but the database is
 > > stopped, that's bad - their commandline will hang indefinitely
 > > rather than just saying, the database isn't running.
 > >
 > > if the retry is in a daemon process that represents that daemon's
 > > normal permanent process of getting work to do, and it wants to
 > > keep retrying until the database is started, that's good.
 > >
 > > but nova, neutron, keystone etc and other services already do
 > this
 > > somehow.   what is the mechanism by which they are doing this?
 > 
 > @Bogdan: have you some info to bring to the Mike's question?"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-26 08:53:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

that's correct but we only give users a tool, right?"}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-03-26 11:07:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> that's correct but we only give users a tool, right?

Indeed, I think we can consider oslo.db as a tool for users.

I think that these changes make sense for the case described in the story (the heat use case).

As I seen on nova, they always give a positive `max_retries` [1] to the wrapper so I don't we'll see side effects on nova.

Other services should explicitely pass this value (`-1`) to activate this behaviour and the actual default value is `10`, so I don't think we risk to face related issues on classic usage and only the aware users aware will activate this behaviour. 

Then if we choose to move further with this feature then we should add a strong warning about hanging [2] (this help text looks wrong).

Also it could be worth to add related doc [3] and associated warn.

As Mike sayed:

> if the retry is infinite in a case where someone is waiting on their > commandline to return a response, but the database is stopped, 
> that's bad - their commandline will hang indefinitely rather than 
> just saying, the database isn't running.

I guess when operators use openstack commands with CLI or execute things through horizon we are in this case where things can hangs indefinitely, but as I sayed previously all service looks like to use positive values for now, and only aware user will activate this (heat in our case) so it will be an isolated, specific, and managed use case.

Please, can you add some doc and warnings to avoid side effects?

Thoughts?

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/search?q=wrap_db_retry&unscoped_q=wrap_db_retry

[2] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/oslo_db/options.py#L84,L86

[3] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.db/blob/master/doc/source/user/usage.rst"}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:58:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> that's correct but we only give users a tool, right?

oslo.db doesn't want to encourage a pattern that is never useful, however.  I've yet to see how this -1 feature is to be used.   Again, services like Nova, Keystone have some non-oslo-db means of eventually connecting to the DB when the DB is down.

do you have a specific place you want to use this feature?"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-26 14:15:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Allow infinite retrying on the expected db errors

When max_retries == -1, retrying becomes infinite.

Story: 2007328
task: 38849

Change-Id: Ib3862fa9c090e185069809fffadd5814d93046eb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

[{'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-10-08 18:58:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-10-10 02:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-10-10 05:29:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

I have added this spec for Ussuri [0] PTG discussion. It will be great if you or anyone on your behalf will be there for the discussion.

[0] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Glance-Ussuri-PTG-planning'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-10-12 01:39:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-10-12 01:49:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

@Abhishek, Thank you for the review!

 > I have added this spec for Ussuri [0] PTG discussion. It will be
 > great if you or anyone on your behalf will be there for the
 > discussion.
 
Yes, I will participate in PTG by three people that include me.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-11-24 23:49:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-11-25 07:34:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

This spec should be targeted to Ussuri and should be submitted in glance_store section'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-11-25 10:51:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2019-11-25 11:28:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-05 15:55:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

I'd love to see s3 support readded. My concern is with how this will be tested and maintained though.

We don't have a requirement in Glance to have third party CI. I think we should, but that's another discussion. I'd just like to see some sort of plan or agreement on how this will be tested and maintained to make sure we don't readd the code only to have it immediately bitrot again."}, {'account_id': 28595, 'date': '2020-01-16 07:37:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

It would be really great to have s3 support back indeed, not only for s3 itself but s3-compatible object storage which are really common on premise, and is a great place to store things like image.

Concerning your testing request, does a single minio process musn't do the trick ? It is used by example by thanos (a way to store prometheus metrics in s3-compatible object storage) for their lab : https://github.com/minio/minio, https://github.com/thanos-io/thanos/blob/master/scripts/quickstart.sh"}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-01-16 15:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Naohiro, are you still working on this, kindly rebase the specs and upload the same, thank you!!'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2020-01-19 10:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 28595, 'date': '2020-01-19 10:29:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Seems to be a good spec, but here is an additionnal point:
- Make reference in your use case and exemples that you can use any s3 compatible storage and not only public aws S3 (by example an extra URL like https://my-object-storage in endpoint url arg)'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2020-01-21 23:39:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Victor, thank you for the review !

> Make reference in your use case and exemples that you can use any s3 compatible storage and not only public aws S3
OK. I forgot to mention S3 compatible storage, so I will fix it soon.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2020-02-12 23:39:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-02-17 06:34:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

Looks good to me!!
Will like to see PoC and doc changes to configure S3 driver before merging this.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-05 15:55:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-03-12 14:12:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

This makes sense, operators have been asking about this.  Thanks for taking it on!'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-03-20 12:27:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

Two quick notes,

One inline, second would be I see no mention about multi-store. Is there anything needed for the s3 driver to work with multi-store?'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2020-03-20 16:13:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 30735, 'date': '2020-03-20 16:18:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)

jokke_, thank you for review.
I fixed the points that were pointed out.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-03-23 05:36:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2020-03-25 14:30:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-03-25 14:36:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:53:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2

Revisions look good.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-03-26 13:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow+1

All agreed to get this done,
Thank you all, Naohiro san!!!'}]

commit_message:
[Q->T] Introduce Queens to Train Upgrade

We introduce Stein images to allow jumping the databases from
Q to S and than to T. This allows us only to do necessary DB sync
for Stein and Train.

Co-Authored-By: jfrancoa@redhat.com, sgolovat@redhat.com, gfidente@redhat.com
Change-Id: I676245ba7c1593343955af5c5698c1a9bb08b7ac

commit_message:
python3: use backported libselinux-python3

It seems that CentOS 7 will not be shipping libselinux-python3
until 7.8 most likely and we need to unblock our gates, so this
will start allowing us to use Python 3 within CentOS 7.

Change-Id: Ia7545d10bffe92c9ef74cbbf44d5e3b3cb356158
(cherry picked from commit fb1a66e0374337f817e18b61e77d7186e2b674e4)

commit_message:
python3: use backported libselinux-python3

It seems that CentOS 7 will not be shipping libselinux-python3
until 7.8 most likely and we need to unblock our gates, so this
will start allowing us to use Python 3 within CentOS 7.

Change-Id: Ia7545d10bffe92c9ef74cbbf44d5e3b3cb356158

commit_message:
Remove async from introspection

Remove async task from introspection, it will fail in case of
timeout due to node_timeout config
Set max_retries to 1 not to waste time and resources
In case we don't have info about nodes, something definitely went
wrong and let's fail it.
Change-Id: Ie4fbcc5fa0370832c0cf3eb5c5b363f380595db4

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-24 20:14:08.000000000', 'message': 'Make ceph-ansible run handle missing "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key"

The SSH private key will normally be in $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo
so if that key is present, then use it. This is a more reliable
location than "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key", which will go away
with Mistral. This change is also backwards compatible as it
will fall back to using "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key" in the case
that $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo is missing. Covers one extra case
where CephAnsibleEnvironmentVariables/ANSIBLE_PRIVATE_KEY_FILE
might have been needed.

Also switches nodes_uuid_command to use ceph-ansible's ansible.cfg as
config-download may not always provide "{{ playbook_dir }}/ansible.cfg"

Change-Id: Ic7e20844877492d7c4b85f7579e90f6c9de355ec
Closes-Bug: #1868864
'}]
commit_message:
Make ceph-ansible run handle missing "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key"

The SSH private key will normally be in $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo
so if that key is present, then use it. This is a more reliable
location than "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key", which will go away
with Mistral. This change is also backwards compatible as it
will fall back to using "{{ playbook_dir }}/ssh_key" in the case
that $HOME/.ssh/id_rsa_tripleo is missing. Covers one extra case
where CephAnsibleEnvironmentVariables/ANSIBLE_PRIVATE_KEY_FILE
might have been needed.

Also switches nodes_uuid_command to use ceph-ansible's ansible.cfg as
config-download may not always provide "{{ playbook_dir }}/ansible.cfg"

Change-Id: Ic7e20844877492d7c4b85f7579e90f6c9de355ec
Closes-Bug: #1868864

commit_message:
Disable fact gathering for create_admin

The create_admin execution doesn't require facts as the tasks are
static. Fact gather can be a long time on systems with large number of
network interfaces or storage volumes. This can lead to timeouts when
doing actions like scaling or deploying.

Change-Id: I0ff270dfabab2ef6926b8d2818ef5087eb03bed9
Closes-Bug: #1869018

commit_message:
Skip proxy tasks when not needed

if rhsm_rhsm_proxy_hostname is not defined, we don't need to run the
tasks used to configure proxy bits.

Change-Id: I15b70179ced343a1abbbb3ca8bd24fed50bfd758

[{'created': '2019-06-21 20:18:59.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] use domain capablites to get supported device models

This change starts to extend the domain capablity parsing
that was added for sev to decode the support disk buses
and storage buses.

Change-Id: I0bdf9ccf7bf3fb1f3136c1e4267b9c99732908d5

Change-Id: I0bdf9ccf7bf3fb1f3136c1e4267b9c99732908d5
'}, {'created': '2019-07-22 20:36:59.000000000', 'message': 'use domain capablites to get supported device models

This change extends parsing of domain capablity xml
to discover the supported storage and video models.

This change alters the behavior of _get_storage_bus_traits
to prefer the data from the domain capabilities api for qemu
and kvm virt types and fall back to generating the storage
traits statically for other virt_types

This change extends the libvirt driver with a
_get_video_model_traits function to generate set of video
models supported by this host form the libvirt domain
capabilites data.

Change-Id: I0bdf9ccf7bf3fb1f3136c1e4267b9c99732908d5
'}, {'created': '2019-07-23 20:54:26.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: use domain capablites to get supported device models

This change extends parsing of domain capablity xml
to discover the supported storage and video models.

This change alters the behavior of _get_storage_bus_traits
to prefer the data from the domain capabilities api for qemu
and kvm virt types and fall back to generating the storage
traits statically for other virt_types

This change extends the libvirt driver with a
_get_video_model_traits function to generate set of video
models supported by this host form the libvirt domain
capabilites data.

This change adds support for generating
"COMPUTE_NET_VIF_MODEL_* traits statically based on the
enabled virt driver.

Change-Id: I0bdf9ccf7bf3fb1f3136c1e4267b9c99732908d5

This change alters the behavior of _get_storage_bus_traits
to prefer the data from the domain capabilities api for qemu
and kvm virt types and fall back to generating the storage

This change extends the libvirt driver with a

This change alters the behavior of _get_storage_bus_traits
to prefer the data from the domain capabilities api for qemu

models supported by this host form the libvirt domain
capabilites data.

to avoid recalculating them every time

This change extends parsing of domain capability XML to discover the
supported storage and video models. To do this, we alter the behavior of
'_get_storage_bus_traits' to prefer the data from the domain
capabilities API for 'qemu' and 'kvm' virt types, only falling back to

avoid the need to recalculating them every time 'update_provider_tree' is
called. This is okay since these things will not change during runtime.

commit_message:
libvirt: Use domain capabilities to get supported device models

This change extends parsing of domain capability XML to discover the
supported storage and video models. To do this, we alter the behavior of
'_get_storage_bus_traits' to prefer the data from the domain
capabilities API for 'qemu' and 'kvm' virt types, only falling back to
generating the storage traits statically for other virt types.

In addition, we extend the libvirt driver with '_get_video_model_traits'
and '_get_vif_model_traits' functions to generate sets of video models
and VIF models respectively that are supported by this host.

Finally, we start caching the static driver traits in a property to
avoid the need to recalculating them every time 'update_provider_tree' is
called. This is okay since these things will not change during runtime
unless libvirt or QEMU are upgraded, in which case the user really
should be restarting consumers of libvirt such as nova anyway.

Change-Id: I0bdf9ccf7bf3fb1f3136c1e4267b9c99732908d5
Partially-Implements: blueprint image-metadata-prefiltering

In order to let infrared discover the ansible role during
plugin execution, roles_path value needs to be added to
infrared_plugin/plugin.spec under config section.
roles_path relatively points to the ansible role which in
our case is ../ (relative path from infrared_plugin folder
to the top level of the repository = role)

This review is dependend on the infrared's one:

Change-Id: I700daaa07a59c3f8e2260b0a31a56f0873634fd3
"}]
commit_message:
Infrared plugin, add roles_path

In order to let infrared discover the ansible role during
plugin execution, roles_path value needs to be added to
infrared_plugin/plugin.spec under config section.
roles_path relatively points to the ansible role which in
our case is ../ (relative path from infrared_plugin folder
to the top level of the repository = role)

This review is dependend on the infrared's one:
https://review.gerrithub.io/c/redhat-openstack/infrared/+/486423

Change-Id: I700daaa07a59c3f8e2260b0a31a56f0873634fd3

subject: rabbitmq_bundle: remove file resources which manage the cookie
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-25 19:52:11.000000000', 'message': "rabbitmq_bundle: remove file resources which manage the cookie

Since we containerized RabbitMQ in Pacemaker, the Kolla bootstrap script
already takes care of writting the cookie file and if the file exists
(like it was the case before that patch since puppet would override it
with the same content), Kolla will remove it and re-creates:

https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/src/branch/master/docker/rabbitmq/extend_start.sh#L15

So this is not necessary to use Puppet to generate that file, let's make
sure we let kolla doing its job and avoid container restarts if the new
config is detected for some reason.

Change-Id: Id4d59e0e16153dc6445d8a9fe20f2e39d7378eb4
"}]
commit_message:
rabbitmq_bundle: remove file resources which manage the cookie

Since we containerized RabbitMQ in Pacemaker, the Kolla bootstrap script
already takes care of writting the cookie file and if the file exists
(like it was the case before that patch since puppet would override it
with the same content), Kolla will remove it and re-creates:

https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/src/branch/master/docker/rabbitmq/extend_start.sh#L15

So this is not necessary to use Puppet to generate that file, let's make
sure we let kolla doing its job and avoid container restarts if the new
config is detected for some reason.

Change-Id: Id4d59e0e16153dc6445d8a9fe20f2e39d7378eb4

subject: Fix get_failed_containers() to correctly fetch container_data
messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-03-26 02:00:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-03-26 02:02:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2020-03-26 09:41:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-26 02:00:40.000000000', 'message': "Fix get_failed_containers() to correctly fetch container_data

To avoid this error:
The error was: KeyError: 'container_data'

We need to fetch container_data from async_result_item in the async
results; that's where the key is. Updating unit tests as well, and the
task which creates the facts so there is no confusion in the logs.

Change-Id: I2a5533335151c4b292e85aea310adfdc44ab1e02
"}]
commit_message:
Fix get_failed_containers() to correctly fetch container_data

To avoid this error:
The error was: KeyError: 'container_data'

We need to fetch container_data from async_result_item in the async
results; that's where the key is. Updating unit tests as well, and the
task which creates the facts so there is no confusion in the logs.

Change-Id: I2a5533335151c4b292e85aea310adfdc44ab1e02

Create a method for bulk assignment of IP addresses within the ipam
driver, to support bulk creation of ports.

This also changes the logic for how the window of available IP addresses
to assign from is calculated within the neutrondb IPAM driver.  The
Python random module is used to produce a statistically sampled set of
IP addresses out of the set of available IPs; this will facilitate
collission avoidance.  When requesting multiple IP addresses the
selection window sized is increased significantly to ensure a larger
number of available IPs, but caps are placed on the amount to make sure
we do not transgress system limits when building pools of IPv6
addresses.

Change-Id: Iad8088eaa261b07153fa358ae34b9a2442bc2a3e
Implements: blueprint speed-up-neutron-bulk-creation
'}]
commit_message:
Add bulk IP address assignment to ipam driver

Create a method for bulk assignment of IP addresses within the ipam
driver, to support bulk creation of ports.

This also changes the logic for how the window of available IP addresses
to assign from is calculated within the neutrondb IPAM driver.  The
Python random module is used to produce a statistically sampled set of
IP addresses out of the set of available IPs; this will facilitate
collission avoidance.  When requesting multiple IP addresses the
selection window sized is increased significantly to ensure a larger
number of available IPs, but caps are placed on the amount to make sure
we do not transgress system limits when building pools of IPv6
addresses.

Change-Id: Iad8088eaa261b07153fa358ae34b9a2442bc2a3e
Implements: blueprint speed-up-neutron-bulk-creation

[{'created': '2020-03-25 18:59:33.000000000', 'message': 'Release manila 9.1.1 off of stable/train

Includes fixes for:
- Bug #1853805 (python3 compatibility in the VNX/PowerMax drivers)
- Bug #1859775 (Quotas logging message fix)
- Bug #1859785 (database optimization for api query)
- Bug #1861485 (CVE-2020-9543)
- Bug #1654598 (policy check for export locations api)

Also includes a fix to the reference "generic" driver
to not fail share creation if manila already has access
to the storage administrator network.

Change-Id: I6fb07ce56a4979179242b96399e563150dc958a4
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Release manila 9.1.1 off of stable/train

Includes fixes for:
- Bug #1853805 (python3 compatibility in the VNX/PowerMax drivers)
- Bug #1859775 (Quotas logging message fix)
- Bug #1859785 (database optimization for api query)
- Bug #1861485 (CVE-2020-9543)
- Bug #1654598 (policy check for export locations api)

Also includes a fix to the reference "generic" driver
to not fail share creation if manila already has access
to the storage administrator network.

Change-Id: I6fb07ce56a4979179242b96399e563150dc958a4
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Release manila 8.1.1 off of stable/stein

Includes fixes for:
- Bug #1853805 (python3 compatibility in the VNX/PowerMax drivers)
- Bug #1859775 (Quotas logging message fix)
- Bug #1859785 (database optimization for api query)
- Bug #1861485 (CVE-2020-9543)
- Bug #1654598 (policy check for export locations api)

Change-Id: Ic70ea5384ea82a0663646f0b25a1eae5ae6e7aaa
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

[{'account_id': 8878, 'date': '2020-01-29 06:58:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-01-29 10:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(7 comments)

Hello,

See my inline thoughts:'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2020-02-06 19:22:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

I have some additional comments.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-02-20 22:53:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

I think it's worth noting that oslo.metrics has already been written downstream at Line, and there is a lot of interest in it from the operator community. I don't want to say the spec is a formality, but the spec is kind of a formality. :-)

What I think might be of more interest is to see what the existing version of the library looks like. Has the code been posted publicly anywhere yet? That will be a pre-requisite to adopting it into the OpenStack ecosystem anyway.

Once we have the code, we can look at what, if anything, needs to be changed to address security, performance, or any other concerns."}, {'account_id': 11583, 'date': '2020-02-24 15:54:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-04 21:38:06.000000000', 'message': 'remove DISTINCT ON SQL instruction that does nothing on MySQL

The SQLAlchemy ORM call ``.distinct('host')`` indicates that
an expression such as "DISTINCT ON host" should be rendered.
However, this syntax is only available on PostgreSQL.   When run
on any other backend, the expression delivers SQL "DISTINCT"
and the additional expressions are ignored.

An upcoming version of SQLAlchemy will begin to warn when
"DISTINCT ON" is called for on a backend that does not support it,
as the semantics of "DISTINCT ON <col>" are quite different from
"DISTINCT".   As Openstack targets MySQL primarily with SQLite
used for unit tests, it should already be guaranteed that
this query only needs to be rendering "DISTINCT" in order to pass
current tests and use cases, since that's all that's being rendered.

Change-Id: I267c6f772d514b442c8c3356c2babc1fe98a8b97
References: https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/4002
'}, {'created': '2020-02-04 23:30:37.000000000', 'message': 'remove DISTINCT ON SQL instruction that does nothing on MySQL

The SQLAlchemy ORM call ``.distinct('host')`` indicates that
an expression such as "DISTINCT ON host" should be rendered.
However, this syntax is only available on PostgreSQL.   When run
on any other backend, the expression delivers SQL "DISTINCT"
and the additional expressions are ignored.

An upcoming version of SQLAlchemy will begin to warn when
"DISTINCT ON" is called for on a backend that does not support it,
as the semantics of "DISTINCT ON <col>" are quite different from
"DISTINCT".   As Openstack targets MySQL primarily with SQLite
used for unit tests, it should already be guaranteed that
this query only needs to be rendering "DISTINCT" in order to pass
current tests and use cases, since that's all that's being rendered.

Change-Id: I267c6f772d514b442c8c3356c2babc1fe98a8b97
References: https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/4002
'}]
commit_message:
remove DISTINCT ON SQL instruction that does nothing on MySQL

The SQLAlchemy ORM call ``.distinct('host')`` indicates that
an expression such as "DISTINCT ON host" should be rendered.
However, this syntax is only available on PostgreSQL.   When run
on any other backend, the expression delivers SQL "DISTINCT"
and the additional expressions are ignored.

An upcoming version of SQLAlchemy will begin to warn when
"DISTINCT ON" is called for on a backend that does not support it,
as the semantics of "DISTINCT ON <col>" are quite different from
"DISTINCT".   As Openstack targets MySQL primarily with SQLite
used for unit tests, it should already be guaranteed that
this query only needs to be rendering "DISTINCT" in order to pass
current tests and use cases, since that's all that's being rendered.

Change-Id: I267c6f772d514b442c8c3356c2babc1fe98a8b97
References: https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/issues/4002

commit_message:
Do not enable nftables service

Enabling the nftables service causes the default values
in /etc/nftables/main.nft to be inserted. These block
UDP traffic, which result in baremetal node inspection
issues on the undercloud.

Related: RHBZ#1814616
Change-Id: If2b5f14d056aee1b0647fc96bb727c81dfefba90

[{'created': '2020-03-26 06:46:11.000000000', 'message': 'Devstack should install the trove-dashboad module by default

Devstack should install both the trove module and the
trove-dashboard module by default. Because the trove-dashboard
is an important package for Trove development. For example,
developers confirm Trove behaviors after they test code change.

trove-dashboard should be explicitly installed by Devstack. Currently
trove dashboard plugin installs trove-dashboard when horizon service
is enabled in local.conf. Thats facing the wrong way. Horizon should
be installed as a required package of trove-dashboard. Because
trove-dashboard is a independent python package of horizon and
trove-dashboard package requires horizon package.

Story: 2007462
Task: 39142
Signed-off-by: Hirotaka Wakabayashi <hiwkby@yahoo.com>
Change-Id: I5a8996d70517b95036b6c95080f2f1e8400cc8f4
